item.title: 2021 & early 2022 news
item.description: Some good news from the past and starting year: Yohan Sahraoui, Laure Carassou and researchers from Biogeco have published in Land Use Planning the results of their investigations regarding how changes in land use in the Bordeaux conurbation will affect ecological connectivity. They have coupled a spatial network model of ecological connectivity to a participatory modelling approach from social sciences. By doing so, they uncovered that the anticipated impacts on ecological connectivity of urban sprawl and densification are unfortunately quite similar to the worst scenarios for future urban development (!

item.title: Estimating survival rates of Gyrfalcons in Iceland
item.description: The annual probability of survival of the average adult individual is a critical parameter for demographic projections of long-lived animal populations. Indeed, small changes to this adult survival rate can yield large changes in the rate of population growth or decline. Yet this parameter was still unknown for the Gyrfalcon, an iconic raptor living in boreal and arctic ecosystems. In a recent PeerJ article1, Ólafur K. Nielsen and I estimate adult as well as juvenile survival rates for the Icelandic population of gyrfalcons.

item.title: Estimation des taux de survie des faucons gerfauts en Islande
item.description: La probabilité annuelle de survie de l’individu adulte moyen est un paramètre critique pour les projections démographiques des populations animales longévives. En effet, de petits changements dans ce taux de survie des adultes peuvent entraîner de grandes variations dans le taux de croissance ou de déclin de la population. item.title: Postdoctoral position in statistical ecology
item.description: I have a new postdoc position opening (details in linked pdf) on improving dynamic models including interactions within and between species, notably their identifiability properties, by combining different kinds of data. I would be open to a variety of candidate profiles, ranging from somebody with statistical or probability background that would focus on mathematical aspects of identifiability, to somebody more interested in fitting dynamic models to data. Don’t hesitate to contact me for an informal chat if you may be interested.

item.title: 2020 News
item.description: Well, this has been a difficult year for everybody and we certainly hope that the end of 2020 has less surprises to offer… That said, amidst the covid-19 chaos, some pieces of good news: Alix started a new position at the French committee for the IUCN this spring. She’s working on the Ecosystem Red List. Congratulations Alix! Gaël Bardon, who studied with Frederic how stage/age structure can help foster coexistence for his MSc “Mathématiques du Vivant” (Polytechnique & AgroParisTech), has successfully defended his thesis.

item.title: 2019 News
item.description: After the holiday break, most of us have good news to share. Yohan just started his tenured lecturer position at University Paris I Sorbonne (UMR 8586 - Prodig). Congratulations Yohan! Coralie has officially started her PhD thesis in phytoplankton dynamics and coexistence in October. She also teaches modeling of dynamic systems and statistics for biology and bioinformatics. Alix extends a bit her current position with us until the end of 2019; she will work with us on the project BiodiverCité on urban pollinators.

item.title: Opportunities
item.description: We host internships for MSc. students (one per year so far) - contact us if interested to work with us, here are our research themes. Every year, Bordeaux’s Idex has a call for postdoctorate fellowships, these will allow to develop your own research project in collaboration with the group. There is also a visiting scholars programme.

item.title: ANTOPTIC
item.description: Xysticus sp. preying on Lobesia botrana in the field © copyright : Sylvie Richart Cervera [INRAE] The ANTOPTIC (Analysis of trophic network to optimize the delivery of natural pest control services) project, led by SAVE and BioGeCo (INRA), aims to answer main two questions: 1) What are the effects of farming practices and landscape context on the structure of arthropod food webs in vineyards? 2) What is the relationship between the structure of arthopod food webs and the levels of pest control ?

item.title: Christelle Aluome
item.description: I am a bio-informatics engineer with a particular expertise in data mining and database development. Generally speaking, I am interested in everything linked with data mining: management, exploitation and analysis (especially for big volumes of data). I used to work in vegetable genomics, in diverse projects related to data mining, which includes database design (associated with the development of a website), analysis of sequences from NGS techniques (Populus nigra, Pisum sativum), the development of procedure for genome reconstruction (de novo assembly) in the case of small computing resources, and the development of protocols for the selection of SNP which can be applied to genotyping chip.

item.title: Frédéric Barraquand
item.description: I am a quantitative ecologist, with interests ranging from population dynamics or coexistence theory to the statistical analysis of time series. Most of my research deals with ecological interactions in a dynamic setting (and sometimes a spatially explicit one). Some more details in my personal webpage. Current projects include, on the technical side: multivariate time series methods to infer causal relationships data fusion techniques for mechanistic ecological models identifiability properties of such models Some fundamental ecological questions that interest me:

item.title: Research Themes
item.description: Research themes and questions Ecology-driven research interests Research in the statistical and theoretical ecology group ranges from behavioural to community ecology Population cycles are regular fluctuations in population size with large amplitude (2-3 orders of magnitude or more). What are their causes? To what extent do predators regulate their prey? How can seemingly similar species manage to coexist? (aka the paradox of the plankton, though this apply to other plant species)

item.title: Back from SFEcologie 2018
item.description: We just came back from SFEcologie 2018 – a great conference in Rennes! Alix presented her latest work on seasonal dynamic food webs; Coralie had a poster on diversity maintenance in (also seasonal) theoretical competitive communities, and myself a presentation of our empirical analyses of phytoplankton community dynamics. I really enjoyed Teja Tscharnkte’s plenary on integrating biodiversity services in agriculture. Teja Tscharntke explains why pollinator diversity is crucial to pollination at #sfe2018 pic.

item.title: Spring 2018 news
item.description: Some highlights from the last few months: April Alix and Frederic were in Clermont-Ferrand at Irstea April 10-12 for the Temporal Network working group meeting of the GDR TheoMoDive. We enjoyed good team spirit and discovered a nice new brew (thanks Franck Jabot for organizing!). Frederic gave a presentation in the Biostatistics seminar at ISPED / Bordeaux Population Health centre on the 23rd: “Inferring interactions between species using time series of population counts and multivariate autoregressive models”.

item.title: BiodiverCité
item.description: The ‘Biodiver’Cité’ project aims at designing guidelines for the preservation of biodiversity in urban landscapes. The first version of this project (2017-2020) had four major objectives : 1) quantify biodiversity in the urban and suburban landscapes of the city of Bordeaux. This is done in a multi-taxa framework, using major groups of terrestrial and aquatic fauna, based on historical databases as well as new data collection (groups targeted include butterflies, damselflies, dragonflies, amphibians, fishes)

item.title: EPIZHONE
item.description: Study zone (Water Streams © BD Cartage ; Wetlands © Adour-Garonne Water Agency ; Superficial water masses © SDAGE) In collaboration with Gretha, EPOC and IRSTEA research teams, we aim to characterize the wetland biodiversity of the area of Les Jalles-Blanquefort on the Gironde estuary. We partner with local observatories regarding biological data sets, in an attempt to gather information on both flora and fauna in the area.

item.title: Phytoplankton dynamics
item.description: Time series analysis In collaboration with Ifremer Arcachon, we work on phytoplankton community dynamics, especially diatoms (one of the most abundant classes of plankton, actively involved in biogeochemical cycles). We are particularly interested in: Drivers of blooms Coexistence mechanisms Our research combines long-term data with statistical and theoretical models. Our analyses of the time series in Arcachon Bay can be found in Barraquand et al. 2018, Oikos. This work has been extended to the French coastline in Picoche et al.

item.title: Coralie Picoche
item.description: I am currently a PhD student at the Institute of Mathematics of Bordeaux, working on fine-scale modelling of phytoplanktonic community dynamics. Brief CV : 2015-2019: Research assistant, in quantitative ecology at the University of Bordeaux, Integrative and Theoretical Ecology group (France) 2014 : Research assistant in fishery modelling, at the Institute of Research for Development, Exploited Marine Ecosystems Department (South Africa) 2012-2013 : Research assistant in shellfish modelling, at the French Research Institute for Exploitation of the Sea (France).

item.title: Alix Sauve
item.description: I now work as a project officer for the French Comittee of the IUCN, in charge of the Red List of Ecosystems As a community ecologist, I am keen on investigating the structure of ecological communities as well as their dynamics, so as to understand how they respond to disturbances. I study ecological communities as networks of interactions, trying to capture the architecture of such webs, their variabilities and their dynamics.

item.title: Laure Carassou
item.description: My main research interest is aquatic ecology, mainly fish assemblage dynamics. I have been studying fish in a variety of ecosystems (estuaries, coral reefs or other coastal and pelagic marine environments from Europe, south Pacific, northern Gulf of Mexico, west and south Africa, northwest Indian Ocean). I combine diverse methodological approaches to provide a comprehensive understanding of the dynamics of fish populations in the context of climatic and environmental variability (trophic studies based on gut contents, stable isotopes, fatty acids, and/or multivariate statistical approaches).

item.title: Matthieu Paquet
item.description:
I am interested in behavioral ecology and population dynamics. I aim to better understand and predict population fluctuations by integrating information on interactions within (e.g. parental effects and social behaviour) as well as among species (e.g. competition and predation), notably using data integration (Integrated Population and Community Models).
I currently work with Frederic Barraquand on the identifiability of dynamic models including interactions within and between species (Integrated Community Models).
